Explore (Digging In)

Providing for Individual Needs

  • Students may be able to make sense of many statements. Every student does not need to understand every statement at this time. Use questions to push their thinking. Then, take note of which types of comparison statements students will need to revisit and make sense of as you progress through the unit.
  • Considerations for each statement: As students discuss the statements in their groups, you can ask questions to hep students azalyze the statements. (Problem- Solving Environment)

Unit Rate #1:

10 meters in 4 seconds

÷ 10 ⤹ ⤸ ÷ 10

1 meter in 0.4 seconds.

Unit Rate #2:

10 meters in 4 seconds

÷ 4 ⤹ ⤸ ÷ 4

2.5 meters in 1 second.

Students may not know which one to use. While both are accurate unit rates, a specific rate is asked for in the Initial Challenge. You can use the “for every” language from Grade 6 Comparing Quantities to help students analyze which rate to use for this problem.

  • Your walking rate was 10 meters for every 4 seconds. (Using the values from the student’s walking.) There are two unit rates. Do we need to find how many seconds for every 1 meter? Or how many meters for every 1 second?
  • Have the student or group look back at the question in the Initial Challenge to see that it asks for meters per second. Does meters per second mean for every 1 meter or for every 1 second? (“per second” means for every 1 second)

Discuss these ideas in the Summary.

While students are answering the questions in the What If Situations, note their strategies for finding answers to the questions.

  • Are students scaling the ratios?
  • Are students using a table?
  • Are students using a graph?

These various strategies can be discussed in the Summarize.

As students complete the experiment and record their data, have them continue on to the What If Situation questions.

The way that students answer the What If...? Situation questions can provide a formative assessment of the strategies that students have for answering the questions in the unit. This will help you assess the types of questions that you will need to ask as you continue in the unit.

Planning for the Summary

What evidence will you use in the Summary to clarify and deepen understanding of the Now What Do You Know? What will you do if you do not have evidence?

Now What Do You Know?

Describe how the distance you walk at a constant rate of time is represented in an equation and graph.

(As you are circulating during the Explore, listen to the way students are using their walking rate- are they using “for every” language; are they looking at scaling them up or down to fit the situation; are they seeing this constant rate in the graph; are they using a unit rate in an equation? Find examples from student work to use in the summary.)
